text: I think that Simon is a brilliant
Economist and the essay that he wrote in
the Atlantic was terrific uh as it
happen Simon and I uh have known each
other for a long time and share a
background in being involved me
reporting Simon as an economist uh in
the collapse of the former Soviet Union
and I think that it was that
mindset which shaped Simon's
intellectual response and
and offered him a prism through which to
look at the relationships between
government and the big Banks here and
see I think that Simon would absolutely
agree that there's not the sort of crony
capitalism here that you would see in
Russia but but to see some similarities
one thing that I think has become much
clearer in the wake of the crisis which
was maybe not so apparent beforehand is
the extent to
which
intellectually uh
we
were ill equipped to really understand
the Dynamics of what were going on in
the developed Western capitalist
economies and and I do think that one of
the things which happened was with the
collapse of
communism a lot of us and and and not
just people who had a vested financial
interest in this but also academics
journalists policy makers a lot of us
really bought into for for the best of
possible reasons the sort of end of
History argument uh the Francis fukuyama
view that this big economic question
which was the big question of the 20th
century of what sort of economic system
do you want a communist system or
capitalist system had been definitively
answered by the collapse of the Soviet
Union and arguably by China's effective
Embrace of a market economy as
well and I think I think that's right I
I I think that big question has been
answered but I think what we then
collectively tended to do is
assume therefore that questions of
political economy were no longer so
Central and that it wasn't so important
in thinking about the economic rules of
the game to think about you know those
very basic even sort of marxist
questions about who benefits and who
loses from any particular economic setup
I think what we tended to
start thinking uh the intellectual
toolkit which we used in thinking about
economic decisions was really more
engineering and we started to think that
the big questions were going to be
resolved just by sort of smart people
getting together figuring out what works
best and that that was the way that sort
of very
pragmatic uh approach was going to be
the way that big economic questions got
resolved I think there's still something
to that and certainly you know when we
write editorials in the financial times
that's the sort of approach which we try
to have but what I think we collectively
stopped thinking about was stopped
really properly focusing on was that
when these big issues when legislation
about financial regulation for example
uh gets actually hammered out by
legislators political economy enters
into it and it's incredibly important to
be thinking about which particular
interests which particular companies are
going to benefit from this version of
the law and which companies are going to
benefit from that version of the law and
it would be absolutely
naive
not to appreciate that that's what
lobbyists are for and also naive not to
appreciate that as companies become
bigger and more powerful they have more
resources to throw into that lobbying
game I don't think there's any anything
wrong with that uh that's Democratic
politics everyone ought to and and does
Lobby for their own interests but I do
think that we as business journalists
and I would also say the community of
economists need to factor into the
equation a little bit more uh this
notion this appreciation of the fact
that when there are debates for example
over the regulation of credit
derivatives I think that's the hottest
one in this space right now it's not
purely about intellectually opposing
points of view uh it's also about
players on different sides of the debate
standing to make or lose a very great
deal of money and we fail our readers uh
legislators fail their voters when they
don't make clear
that this particular way of regulating
this particular Market will make Bank X
much much richer and maybe we'll carry
the collective costs of Y and
Z I would disagree with part of of
Scott's premise uh which is first of all
implicit in the question is the notion
that we were in a period that we are in
a period of deflation
and also implicit in the question is
that a lot of the unconventional tools
of monetary policy weren't used uh I do
think actually a lot of unconventional
tools of monetary policy were used and
one of the most creative players in the
crisis turns out to have been Ben banki
with mvin King not too far behind so we
did have we did have and continue to
have all sorts of unconventional forms
of liquidity being injected into the
markets by the world Central bankers
now that you know once they hit that
zero rate where they couldn't use
interest rates to Gin up the economy we
have seen them using many many
unconventional tools to try to pump more
money into the economy so actually I do
think we have seen all sorts of
unconventional monetary policy
responses uh and I do also think you
know certainly journalists at the
financial times are very well aware of
you know the two economic Ms that
government has monetary policy and
fiscal policy and I think we've written
with real sophistication about the
monetary debate and then also about the
fiscal debate so actually uh I think
both that we've had more creative
monetary policies than as Scott would
imply in his question but also that at
the moments of decision uh I think that
we were quite thought and explicit in
talking about what those options
were I think to assess the links between
the Obama Administration and business is
a really big really complicated question
and in some ways it's still too early to
answer it they haven't been in office
for a full year uh and I think that
there are different
questions that need to be asked about
the Obama Administration in different
areas so there's one set of issues in
healthare there's one set of issues in
the environment and climate change and
there's one set of issues in financial
services to take Financial Services I
think that there really you know
fairness requires that we divide the
response of the Obama Administration
into two Parts uh the first is the
immediate crisis
firefighting and there I think we
really have to be careful not to apply
the rules of calmness of the markets
having recovered of the Second Great
Depression no longer seeming to be a
possibility that might start tomorrow we
have to be careful not to apply that
mindset to the decisions that were taken
in the crisis and we also have to be
mindful of the fact that the really big
decisions about the financial crisis
were all taken when George Bush was
still president now it is true that
Barack
Obama made the explicit Choice
effectively to carry on with those
policies by promoting Tim gner from
being the head of the New York fed to
being his Secretary of the Treasury even
so the big decisions were already in
place where I
think the Obama Administration has a
much
clearer much Freer choice to make in its
relationship with the banking industry
is the post crisis is what the
Regulatory and legislative response is
to this crisis and there we haven't yet
seen I think a very robust response yet
we we had a choice by the White House to
move on Health Care before moving on
financial reform and in financial reform
we have not yet
seen a sufficiently in my view
aggressive response I do think that the
right thing for this Administration for
any Administration to do is to say
actually the rules of the game were a
real problem ahead of the financial
crisis and while before this crisis
maybe people reasonable people could
legitimately disagree about the extent
to which markets self-regulate this
crisis really is proof that they can't
self-regulate and that booms and busts
still do happen and most importantly
that the collective cost of those booms
and busts is really great and that is
what gives government a right and indeed
a responsibility to regulate in such a
way that minimizes both the likelihood
of those booms and busts and more
importantly the the itive cost of those
booms and Buss and I think the
responsibility of government to do that
absolutely
outweighs
both the pen the growth penalty because
if you do have regulation that does
inevitably cut down on Innovation and it
means that in your boom period your boom
is a little bit less vigorous uh and it
also really means that government has a
right to restrict the ability to grow of
specific players and of specific firms
